awd_titl_txt: Formal Models Of Traditional Milling Tool Design
awd_abstract_narration:
Archaeology, through reconstruction of past behaviors and how they emerge and adapt over time, has the potential to provide insight into processes which shape human behavior and social organization today. To accomplish this goal it is necessary to have robust analytic tools which permit researchers to move from objects excavated from the ground to conclusions regarding the behaviors of people responsible for their discard. This project is important because it assists in developing such techniques.

With National Science Foundation support, Dr. Tammy Buonasera will begin a series of experiments using replicas of prehistoric ground stone milling tools (manos and metates and mortars and pestles) to generate empirically informed models of ground stone processing efficiency. These models will help evaluate relationships between ground stone technology, mobility, and resource use among prehistoric hunter-gatherers. The significance of the project rests on  its potential to increase  knowledge of economic decisions made by individuals engaged in plant food processing. In many contexts around the world, changes in the form and frequency of ground stone milling tools play key roles in reconstructing sequences of resource intensification, sedentism, and plant domestication. Despite this, there are few empirically grounded comparisons of the relative efficiency of different milling tool-resource combinations in the literature.  Rather, links between form and function typically rest on commonsense notions of efficiency or "suitability." This study will provide better estimates than we now have for defining when it would be profitable to shift between grinding technologies, and results will be widely applicable to studies of ground stone function and resource use in many places and times. 


The proposed project will begin with a series of controlled experiments designed to measure and compare the efficiency of five different forms (three mortar and two metate shapes), and two different raw materials (a harder and a softer stone), for processing four resources with different physical characteristics (acorns, small hard seeds, tule roots, and ocher). Because this research aims to provide data for modeling tool design choices among hunters and gatherers with varying degrees of mobility (i.e., from conditions of high residential mobility, where food is not stored, to semi-sedentary contexts, where food storage may be critical), experiments will also compare grinding efficiency and use-wear patterns for fresh and dried versions of the plant resources (acorns, small hard seeds, tule roots). Simple optimization models will be used to compare experimental estimates of food processing labor and costs of tool manufacture against overall productivity. Ultimately, this research will improve knowledge about relationships between grinding tool designs and economic decisions made by individuals engaged in food processing. It will also contribute to improving interpretations of use-wear patterns on ground stone tools. The project will be completed over a two-year period with the help of community volunteers and university students who will participate in the experimental process.  The project will also produce both a physical and a digital reference set for future use-wear analysis.

por.por_cntn:
Funding for this project helped generate new data and analytical approaches that will aid archaeologists in reconstructing behavioral information from ground stone milling tools?a historically understudied but common technology that is typically associated with women?s labor and routine subsistence activities. Ethnographic examples, worldwide, indicate that women do the bulk of plant food gathering and processing in hunter-gatherer societies. Ground stone milling tools, similar to the ones used in this project, are often an integral part of these tasks. To the extent that we can project a gendered division of labor into the past, this project has contributed new ways of looking into the daily lives and economic decisions made by women in prehistoric hunting and gathering societies.

The intellectual merit of the project rests on its potential to increase our knowledge of economic decisions made by individuals, probably women, who were engaged in plant food processing. This is important to a broader understanding of human adaptative strategies because changes in the form and frequency of ground stone milling tools play key roles in reconstructing sequences of resource intensification, sedentism, and plant domestication in many archaeological contexts around the world. Prior to this project, few empirically generated data existed to compare the relative efficiency of different milling tool designs for processing various types of wild plant resources. Instead, links between form and function have typically rested on commonsense notions of "suitability

A series of controlled experiments using replicas of prehistoric ground stone milling tools were conducted to generate reproducible data that could be compared with simple optimality models. These models aim to evaluate relationships between ground stone technology, mobility, and resource use among prehistoric hunter-gatherers who had a marked reliance on plant foods.

The experiments were structured to engage students, professional archaeologists, and community members in collecting data on the productive potential of different tool milling forms. Participants used five different forms (shallow mortar, deep conical mortar, deep bowl mortar, shallow basin grinding slab, and a flat grinding slab) manufactured from two different raw materials (sandstone and basalt) to process three different materials (small wild grass seeds, and two types of acorns). Milling tool designs were selected because they are common?in different sequences and combinations?across a number of prehistoric hunter-gatherer and low-level food producing contexts worldwide. The foods were selected to represent basic categories of plant foods (acorns/nuts, wild grass seeds) that have made major dietary contributions to hunter gatherers and were frequently processed into flour to increase their nutrition and edibility. These resources also have very different physical properties, which could influence design choices for ground stone milling tools.  

Data from 140 individual milling tasks, conducted under controlled conditions and measured using standardized techniques, were combined to provide comparable and reproducible base-line data on the processing efficiency of different tool types. These data have been modeled and evaluated in reference to manufacturing costs, mobility, and resource use to better understand conditions that could have favored a shift between particular grinding technologies. Results and raw data have been published in academic journals and presented at professional meetings.

The project has also produced physical and digital reference sets of microscopic use-wear that are available to other researchers. Physical and digital reference materials help to link patterns of observable wear to the processing of broad resource types such as small, hard seeds or large fleshy nuts and acorns. Digital reference materials are available on the Digital Archaeological Record (t-DAR) at  https://core.tdar.org/project/440565/ground-stone-use-wear-digital-reference-materials, and the Center for Experimental Archaeology at the University of California, Davis (CEAD) at http://cead.ucdavis.edu/ground-stone-use-wear.html.

Broader impacts of the project were generated by involving students and members of the public in the experiments. The experimental grinding sessions provided a vehicle for individuals to learn about the experimental process and major economic shifts in human prehistory. The project also provided training and independent research opportunities for several graduate and undergraduate students.
